samples.context: Some organisms use simple food material obtained from inorganic sources in the form of carbon dioxide and water. These organisms, the autotrophs, include green plants and some bacteria.
samples.question: What are autotrophs and their sources?

samples.context: Other organisms utilise complex substances. These complex substances have to be broken down into simpler ones before they can be used for the upkeep and growth of the body.
samples.question: How do heterotrophs obtain their food?

samples.context: To achieve this, organisms use bio-catalysts called enzymes. Thus, the heterotrophs' survival depends directly or indirectly on autotrophs.
samples.question: What role do enzymes play in digestion?

samples.context: Even when we are not doing any apparent activity, energy is needed to maintain a state of order in our body. We also need materials from outside in order to grow, develop, synthesise protein and other substances needed in the body.
samples.question: Why does the body need energy even at rest?

samples.context: This source of energy and materials is the food we eat. How do living things get their food? The general requirement for energy and materials is common in all organisms, but it is fulfilled in different ways.
